subject: RE: [junit] How can I write test case before write concrete cless
msgSnippet: Weiming, It seems to me that if you don t know what the constructor would be, you also wouldn t know what the factory API would be. Inventing the constructor I
messageBody:
Weiming,

It seems to me that if you don't know what the constructor would be, you
also wouldn't know what the factory API would be. Inventing the constructor
I wish I had is part of the story that I tell with my tests. I prefer to do
things simply at first and add abstraction later, so I write tests with
constructors and move to factories later if they become necessary.

Filling in a stub class should limit over-design and help you make your
decisions with as much concrete information as possible.

Good luck,

Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute

> I think factories makes better. Because I do not really know how will
> the constructor be.
>
> And these days my friend told me I can give a dummy class makes all
> methods return null.
> First let the unit test case run, and finish my concrete
> class step by step.
>
> How about this one?
>
> Regards.
>
> Weiming
>
> Kent Beck wrote:
> > Weiming,
> >
> > I can think of several ways you could write your tests. You could
> > write the
> > test with an example of a concrete class and use constructors:
> >
> > IMoney addend= new Money(5, "CHF");
> >
> > You could use factories:
> >
> > IMoney addend= fiveFrancs();
> > or
> > IMoney addend= MoneyFactory.fiveFrancs();
> >
> > The principle I use in such cases is to defer design
> decisions as long as
> > possible. I would start with the variables being declared
> with a concrete
> > class, then introduce interfaces once they would help the code:
> >
> > Money addend= new Money(5, "CHF");
> >
> > Sincerely yours,
> >
> > Kent Beck
> > Three Rivers Institute
> >

> > > Is there any other method to build these cases?
